case_vignette: Two days following the home birth of her son, a mother brings the infant to the pediatric emergency room because of bilious vomiting. He is unable to pass meconium and his abdomen is distended. Endoscopic biopsy of the proximal colon demonstrates an absence of Meissner’s and Auerbach’s plexi in the bowel wall.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Pediatrics and Neonatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
My baby has been vomiting up a greenish substance and hasn't been able to have his first bowel movement. His belly also looks swollen.
How old is your baby?
He is two days old.
Was your baby born full-term or prematurely?
The vignette does not provide this information.
Has your baby passed meconium at any point since birth?
No, he hasn't passed meconium at all.
Does your baby have any other apparent abnormalities or symptoms?
No, the vignette does not mention any other abnormalities or symptoms.
Is there any family history of cystic fibrosis or intestinal issues?
The vignette does not provide information about family history.
**Final Diagnosis:** Hirschsprung disease.

My baby has been throwing up a greenish-yellow liquid and hasn't been able to pass his first stool. His belly also looks swollen.
How old is your baby?
He's two days old.

No, he hasn't passed meconium at all.

**Final Diagnosis:** Hirschsprung's disease.
